Go for your finest resolution and enjoy the printing :)

Paint it

Give it a primer and then paint with some acrylic paint. Fill in the whiskers and inside of the ears with a different color than the rest. Will look very cute.

Tinkercad

I whipped this up in Tinkercad in about 45 minutes or so. Started with a rectangular piece and then just cut away until I was happy, added the ears by using a 3 sided pyramid.

Proudly display your slayed Ork Head on or wall or mantel!

Model will need splitting if you want to print a large model, files include split into half that should fit on most printers. Will need some post printing painting to give it that real life feel.

author: 2chengzzz

title: Power Supply, Raspberry Pi, Relay Module, Fan Case

description.text:
It's a long name but it has multiple uses: cooling down the AC/DC power supply, switching on/off the AC/DC power supply remotely. It is also a Raspberry Pi / Relay Module case.
You can refer to the included connection diagram to see how things are connected inside this case.

Hardware:

  1. Raspberry Pi with Octoprint preloaded and ready to be accessed from a Web Browser. If not, search online to see how to set it up.
  2. A relay module, one channel is good for this purpose but I have 2 channel module installed because I will want to remotely turning on/off other devices (light, music, or anything that will connect to my “future” power bar). With one channel relay module, everything could be turned on/off together with the 3D printer. However, controlling other devices separately might be more practical such as leaving music on and keep the 3D printer off to cool it down after so many hours of usage. The price is about the same for 2 or 1 channel relay module.
  3. A terminal strip (optional but I recommend it for ease of connectivity and power distribution). Please use the electrical ring connectors at all connections if you can, don't be cheap on this because one loose wire can cause a very damaging spark.
  4. Two 40mm fan, 12vdc type of course.
    Also need 3 x M3 screws and 2 nuts on top right, 2 screws and 2 nuts on the bottom right (or #6 3/8” machine screws worked too)
    Use wood screws (such as #6 3/8”) to fasten terminal strip to the frame. Remove existing M3 screw from the power supply (top left) and replace with longer M3 screw (spare from the Anet A8).
    The design could fit different type of Raspberry Pi and/or Relay Module, if you can not snap the board(s) in you could use tie-wrap through the honeycomb holes, double-sided tape or crazy glue to secure the Raspberry and Relay Module to the frame.
    Follow the attached wiring diagram to connect the components together, make sure you orient the Raspberry Pi to have the network cable toward the back or else the network cable might get caught with the X-axis / Z-axis bars & rod. Also connect the fans with label pointing outside to suck the hot air out of the power supply and not blowing dust into it.

Software:
Octopi comes with GPIO already pre-installed, use SSH to login using pi username. To check if it’s available enter command:
gpio readall
If it comes back with information then you are good to go. If not, check wiringpi.com to see how to install.

Wiring Diagram:
In order for the octopi to control the relay, the “live” wire from main power should go to the “live” port #1 on the AC/DC power supply. The neutral line from main power goes to COM port on the relay module. Connect a new neutral line from NO (Normally Open) port on the relay module to the power supply Neutral port #2. Connect the ground straight from main power to the AC/DC power supply ground port #3. A side note about my AC/DC 12vdc power supply, I think the Anet A8 comes with incorrect internal wiring and I “had” to use my neutral line as “COM” line, it should really be the “hot/live” wire to be used as COM line. Well, since I don’t have another 12vdc power supply I can’t verify if All Anet A8 are like that or not. Anyway, the point is to have the Hot wire from main power to the relay’s COM port, then Normally Open (NO) port goes to AC/DC Hot wire. I just show what works for me, you might have to switch live and neutral wires if it does not work for you.

The Raspberry Pi uses the WiringPi connection scheme so check it out and use the proper GPIO pin. To demonstrate the pinout scheme, if you have the same Raspberry Pi Rev B as mine, then the 5vdc is the first pin on the outer row, ground is the third pin, and GPIO 1 is on the 6th pin. Those are NOT the actual pin number, those are for locating where they are on the board. The actual pin for 5vdc is header pin #2, ground is header pin #6, and GPIO is header pin #12. In fact the “gpio readall” command shows the pinout for your board, dont' use the BCM pinout.
Once logged in, edit the file .bashrc and add the following two lines:
alias a8on='gpio mode 1 out;gpio write 1 0'
alias a8off='gpio write 1 1;gpio mode 1 in'

Save and exit, then enter command “source .bashrc” to activate it. If you do your wiring properly, you should be able to enter command “a8on” and see the unit goes up, “a8off” to see it turned off.

Print settings:
I used Repetier to print, needed to move object 7mm on X-axis to the right to center it. Maybe it’s my Repetier setup that was incorrect.

Slicer configuration:
Print settings:
Layer high 0.2mm, Infill 30%, Speed 37mms, Do generate Support Material.
Filament settings: PLA 1.75mm, depending on your filament I set mine to 215 deg for extruder, 65 deg for hot bed.

Update 1: Adding version 3 with stronger and thicker wall (4mm instead of 2mm) and the thin version with higher retaining tabs for the relay module (v2a)

title: BMW K100 Speedometer mount for 80mm Speedo and panel LEDs

description.text:
I searched for a speedometer mount with integrated panel LEDs and a pushbutton for my BMW K100 Cafe Racer and found none...
So i made one by myself for a 80mm Spedometer form MBB :
https://mmb-messtechnik.de/index.php?option=com_virtuemart&view=productdetails&virtuemart_product_id=78&virtuemart_category_id=25&lang=de&Itemid=661

And it works good but the mounting is a bit tricky i used some M6 treads on the upper triple clamp to mount it on the original treat holes for the OEM speedo. It worked with a plier and self securing nuts the only way to tightend the nuts was with a screwdriver and a smal plier and a hammer.... But i wanted a Tight fit and it worked out for me.

title: Laptop transformer strain reliefs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I call these wrap caps. The idea is to reduce cable strain by making the twists on the cable less severe. Now, while wrapping the cable, it can only be bent so sharply before the wrap caps get in the way.

These are designed for use with a Thermaltake LUXA2 EnerG Bar 65W Universal Laptop Adapter (http://www.microcenter.com/product/471927/luxa2_energ_bar_65w_universal_laptop_adapter). The caps are printed in PETG and the band is printed in TPU.

well, for hyperventalation it would help. It'd make it a bit harder to breath in, so would slow breathing to a better level. but I'm confused about the others :/ (same effect as using a paper bag)
Unless you were to use it as a spacer for an inhaler :/
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text: The paper bag for hyperventilation works by decreasing the available oxygen, not restricting breathing.  Making it harder to breath for someone hyperventilating could induce panic and make the situation worse.
comments.author: dan3008

comments.text: well its to restrict more air coming in than is needed so you wil only get the amount of air you need to function. in Holland  doctors already give this to there patients so its nothing new i only dit make it printable for everybody
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text:
Yeh, like i said, same effect.
Anyway, I agree with you totally. I'd actually come to the comments to say it was a bad idea. That said, when I was with St Johns ambulance, we had a not dissimilar device, but we basically attached it to a compressor and used it as a way to mix Ventolin (the relief inhaler) with slightly compressed air.
comments.author: ElmoC

description.text:
This is an easier and quicker option to print than most of the others.
Basically the lite version of my other one.

It gets bolted to the bottom of the acrylic (or any) Z nut mount with the points facing down.
You then lower the mount onto the nut so the points sit in 2 of the holes on the Z nut.
The points can be in line side to side or front to back, but probably better to have them front to back. Try both ways and see if one is better for you.

Added EZGimbal v2
A little more clearance and smoothed the corners for an easier print.

Added "The Purcell"
This needs 2 "The Purcellx2", 1 "The Purcellx1", and 4 .177cal BBs.
The BBs go in one direction on the upper level, and the other direction on the lower level.

You can also use 2 EZGimbal, 1 on the mount, 1 on the nut, and put a "The Purcellx1" in the middle if you dont want to use the balls. The last 3 pics on the right are of this setup.
Currently, I think this is the best option here for what it does, ease of print, and assembly.

description.text:
My attempt at making a standard 2-band puzzle ring. It's not a hard puzzle by any stretch, but it is pretty neat. The different angles that the two rings are printed at have the unintentional effect of giving the two rings slightly different sheens, which adds a nice touch.

I actually had a pretty hard time designing this, and the mess of a timeline that was left once I got the shape I was looking for meant I couldn't really go back and add in tolerances like I had planned, so I might have to revisit this later.

P.S. If someone has a dual extruder machine and can print one with two colors, I'd love to see it!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

This file is designed with an inner diameter of 18mm which is about a size 8 ring. It fits comfortably on my finger of diameter ~16.5mm, as measured by dial calipers without compressing my skin. Scale accordingly if you plan to wear it.

Be sure to check layers view in your slicer, and make sure there's a substantial amount of infill within the ring so that it can survive support removal.

print_settings.Notes:: Print, then once off the hotbed you may use a small pot of boiling water, a small butane torch, or a heat gun to get the end tacky. Once flexible, bend as seen in the photos or as per your preferred flasher shape. You may apply reflective stickers, etc as attractant. In the photos, I've applied epoxy resin with a number of glitter colors added. This makes the part water-tight, adds strength, and a visual attractant.

description.text:
Salmon fenders are extremely expensive for what they are - a piece of plastic that flops around that sorta looks like a school of fish, meant to attract salmon to the bait presented in the terminal tackle a few feet beyond the dodger. These things are $10-20 a pop and are usually just a bent piece of acrylic with some stickers attached. Printing these out of glow in the dark PLA makes them extremely inexpensive and adds an attractant in the manufacturing process.

Initially I attempted to model the bending of the fender into the design and printing, but this added unnecessary complexity. It's preferable to print the part as a simple flat solid, then use the benefit of thermoplastic as a medium to 'massage' the ends of the dodger into it's final, water-floppy shape.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50-100%

Notes:

Print, then once off the hotbed you may use a small pot of boiling water, a small butane torch, or a heat gun to get the end tacky. Once flexible, bend as seen in the photos or as per your preferred flasher shape. You may apply reflective stickers, etc as attractant. In the photos, I've applied epoxy resin with a number of glitter colors added. This makes the part water-tight, adds strength, and a visual attractant.

Yet another worm gear which happens to be throated. Also globoid, as the driven gear has a dish to it as well. One full rotation of the worm should also offset by one tooth on the driven wheel, and since there's 120 teeth, that means 120:1 reduction.

I made this more with cleverness in knowing how to model in Blender rather than using math, so I'd assume there is some error. But I'd also think it's close enough that it's not anything that some 300 or finer grit sandpaper couldn't solve. So this should be a workable gear.

Also I'm thinking of doing something based on this, such as a differential. Nothing too clever though.

description.text: My fishing kayak came with a lowrance mount built-in, but it was place so far forward that it was uncomfortable using it. I tried printing out lilmikey's Lowrance ram mount, but the STL has unjoined faces that intersect, and Simplify3D did not like printing it. No sweat, I imported it into sketchup and used my magic solids toolchain to rejigger it a bit. I didn't like the oddly shaped rail mount, so all that I kept was the actual lowrance clip-mount. I made a railmount version to go on common kayak rail, and another version to mount directly opposite a RAM mount, which is the version I use.

author: quangd

description.text: I created this little voltage display holder. This allows you to crazy glue the display to this unit and attach to any case with whatever method you wish (glue, velcro, hot glue, etc..). It sits on the holder a bit proud but the point of it is to keep the back of the PCB away from anything that could short it out.

description.text: Clips for holding a glass sheet on the Printrbot.

Print off 4 clips, these were designed to work with the heat bed on a Printrbot+ with an 8" square 1/8 sheet of borosilicate glass from McMaster-Carr.
The print had some problems so the clip needed a lot of fine-tuning. After I get my calibration issue fixed I'll see if the clip itself actually needs some adjustment as well.

comments.text: Can anyone think of a reason these won't work on a printrbot LC with 6x6 glass?
comments.author: luckydad

comments.text: Â the "steps" were setup for the 8x8 size, but I it should be close enough to work. You could also try Heeboore's derivative, it would probably work better.
comments.author: luckydad

comments.text: I added the SketchUp file I used to create the clips, it's the plywood bed, printrbot heat bed, and sheet of glass.
comments.author: TechnoSwiss

comments.text: I just got this glass in today. It looks like the total "spare" distance on the diagonal between the M3 bolts and the plate glass is about 3mm. If you modify the distance between the hole and the corner for the glass from ~2.6mm to ~1.5mm it works great. (It's almost exactly where the hole for the bolt head is in your design.) I just cut away where the standard screws are on my parts.
comments.author: cee

comments.text: Glad it was useful.

This is a front cover for my computer's 3.5 inch card reader. It's a cheap card reader from Amazon (brand name CSL). One of the front cover tabs broke and it was constantly falling out, so I modelled a replacement with TinkerCAD. I'm still calibrating my Geeetech Prusa i3 clone, so result it's still a bit rough, but it does the job.

2017/08/13 UPDATE: I just updated the design adding rounded corners and text labels for each connector. Rounded corners are nice, but text is too small to be readable, at least with my printer (0.4 mm nozzle, 0.15 layer height). I'll probably remove labels in future versions, or I'll perhaps keep two versions for those with better printers :-)

Printer:

Geeetech Aluminum Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100%
Just TinkerCAD and a caliber :-)

A simple music box, Movements are cheap and easy to get. It takes the Sankyo style 18 note movements. Has provision for a 20mm long 3mm Allen head screw, that and a spring from a ball point pen, it can operate automatic when lid is opened.

1.75mm filament for hinge.
(2) 6x1.5mm Disk Magnet to hold lid shut.

The feet glue on so you dont have to print with a lot of supports.
Only supports needed is where the screw guide is on the box.

Box lid is plain, We had customized the one i took pictures of.

description.text:
I had trouble attempting to use PolyFlex for a print. It went sideways inside the extruder, stopped the fan, and melted the filament guide I bought from Kodama (in their "Essentials Kit")

So I made one from scratch that leaves very little room for that to happen, and printed it with Polymaker's PC-Plus (which pushed the temperature limits of the Trinus extruder).

I put in cooling channels on the bottom to ensure that it will never melt. But MORE IMPORTANT is the restrictive nature of the filament path to prevent flexible filament from bending sideways.

Printer:

Kodama Trinus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15mm layers

Infill:

30%

Notes:

No need to lay it on its side to print. Vent arches were designed to not be an overhang problem.

TinkerCad

I used to be a machinist, and I still think like one. I started with a block and 2 cylinders, and cut away what I didn't need. After building one I realized that the centerline of the hole for the spring (and the overall body) didn't line up with the actual hot-tube and idler wheel centerlines. But I fixed that.

comments.text: That worked for me! But i made a lil "upgrade" as far as i found it hard to put this thing without disassembling the whole extruder system i made a path for it to slide inside it's place with just the extruder arm off...obviosly it doesnt affect the process=)

OpenDungeonTiles: Wall Interior Short Roughstone 2x2

Assembly:
Walls take 5mm magnetic spheres
Floors take 3mm magnetic spheres
Bases take 5mm magnetic spheres
Insert 5mm magnetic spheres into the 2 holes, glue thinner piece on top. When placing other parts onto the base, the thinner glued on part should be on the bottom. (I am working on assembly video/instructions)

Open Forge Compatible.
Open Lock Compatible (Note: You must use the lock in my files it is thinner)

Glossary:
FullKit
Files marked FULLKIT at the beginning are all the pieces you need to assembly for a full base tiles/corner tile/wall tiles etc... They usually include the base, basecap, floor, floorcap, and walls with wallcap if applicable.
Kit
Files marked KIT at the beginning are the pieces you need to assembly a full tile without the base pieces (because there is a base kit, this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2463765)
KITDUAL
The is the same as a kit, but a files that contains two copies of the part. Cut down on copy paste in slicers.
Something else
These are the individual pieces if you wish to print a single part of the tile. Not all the files are done for these, and you may have to pull them out of the kits. (working on this)

Questions - use the comments, send me a message here or on patreon.

Hello I have set up a Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/opendungeontiles
Why go here, well it helps me give free models to the community and there is even a spot for limited custom requests!

description.text:
Made this as vibration dampening for controller card.
Its just a couple of "cups" with a hole for an M3 screw and a yellow ear protection foam cut at desired length. They are glued together with epoxy so the screw doesn't turn and the foam stays in the cup.
One of the cups have a raised boss on the screw side since some boards have surface mounted components soldered near the mounting holes.

Works like a charm.

comments.text: Is this wearable? You might have trouble printing those knees/thighs at the top of the legs.  I'd recommend not trying to print all of these parts at once.  I'd put the leg into a separate file and try to print it, the body in another and so on.  That way if you realize half way through printing that the knees/thighs are an overhang that won't print properly, you haven't wasted a ton of time up until that point.

title: Duchess Board Game Table Cup Holder Spacer

description.text:
A spacer design for the Duchess Board Game Table cup holders that provides a nice firm support. I was unhappy with how wobbly the cup holders were so I designed a spacer that allows the cup holder to be tightened snug. It's also designed to stay in place by centering on the little screws that hold the metal bracket to the cup holder. I just made them so we'll see how long it stays tight, but they don't wobble anymore!

Selling them here if you don't have a printer: http://www.ebay.com/itm/-/142477757465?

I decided to make a fpv racer for 5" props with a lower cg. I looked at what features I likes best in the alien, chameleon, and Qav quads. After plotting out the motor spacing, I then worked my way up the frame. I will be working on other camera mounts, but is set up for runcam style cams.
The arms are setup for 2204 to 2206 motors and 5" props. I do plan to make some other arms for 4" and 6" props. This will see more changes once I get my motors and fc in.
The main plate is set up for press nuts like https://www.mcmaster.com/#99437a135/=18wxmnj to be placed for mounting the arms. Stack height is limited but this is made to have the battery sit lower as to bring the cg closer to the prop line. This will be best with a flight controller with built in pdb and osd like the f4 omni aio boards.

*** THIS IS STILL IN THE EARLY STAGES AND UNTESTED****

print
2x rear pylon
4x 5in arms (set to 5mm thick for printed arms)
1x of all other parts.

comments.text: I am still in need of getting props and 1500 4s packs for testing :( but bills come first.
comments.author: Dcdesigns

comments.text: The first build came in at 338g without props and bat. The camera mounts and pylons are printed with pla. The remaining part printed with proto pasta's cf pla. The gear used: Kiss fc, tbs mr steele silk motors, multistar 20a esc (will get changed), fat shark 25mw cased vtx, 600 tvl cam, and my own power board. I will be making changes to the main plate and bat plate so they will be thicker, but for now you can adjust the z scale to 1.2 (120%) leaving the x and y at 1.0.

description.text: OK, this isn't anything new that hasn't been tried before, but I was never able to get the ones I saw to work with my specific spools. SO....I went over to Tinker Cad, (Thank you Tinker Cad!), and got out my caliper and went to work... this is the end product. This works with all my M3D 250 ft empty filament rolls. I printed in PLA at 10% infill, but you might want to increase it. I did have to drill a tiny hole, (because I still haven't figured that part out yet). I used the smallest drill bit I could find that fit my wire and put it in the corner and made a hole. I used a piece of solid core speaker wire, stripped, looped through, (see pictures), and it works great. The small clasp just goes on the front to keep it from falling open.

description.text:
The LCD screen on my Monoprice Mini Delta is pretty bright. I designed this little plate to work with some small cylindrical magnets I had on hand.

If the magnets are glued into the holes flush with the raised areas, nothing will touch the LCD screen, but the magnets will be close enough to hold it in place securely. It clicks into place very nicely. :)

I've included the OpenSCAD files, the STL, and even my Gcode if you'd like to print your own.

title: Modular Surround Speaker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
After having made the Modular Sound Bar / Center Speaker (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2446587) I continued my project of making a full set of speakers using my 3D printer. You could already use the modules of the Sound Bar as stereo and surround speakers, but for my situation I needed the speakers to have a little stand. Once I had done that and hooked everything up I found the high frequencies lacking a bit with the speakers I used so I added a tweeter. This is the result, again fully printable without supports. If you compare the sound bar with this unit you will find that I used different speakers - I have ran out of the units I got from China so I used some (more expensive) store bought (JayCar Australia) ones.

As with the sound bar, please let me know how you go if you end up making these.

UPDATED - paths2openscad-3.zip
UPDATED - paths2openscad-2.zip
See Thing 25036 for version 2 and 3
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036 This Thing is an Inkscape extension to export Inkscape paths to OpenSCAD. There has been at least one prior Thing attempting this, Thing #9376. However, it only handled a small subset of SVG. This extension handles SVG arcs, clones, circles, ellipses, groups, lines, paths, polygons, polylines, rects, and splines. It also follows document transforms as well as viewports. Either an entire document or just the selected portions of a document are processed. SVG text must first be converted to a path within Inkscape using Inkscape's "Path > Object to Path" menu item. Note that another approach to importing SVG into OpenSCAD is to save the SVG to DXF from within Inkscape. Then use OpenSCAD's import() function to import the DXF. [Older versions of OpenSCAD used import_dxf().] Much of the core code in this extension is derived from work done by myself and others while developing the Inkscape driver for the Eggbot. 9 May 2013: Modified the code to remove non alphanumeric characters from the names of the generated OpenSCAD modules. 15 June 2012: Added support for a single level of polygon nesting. I.e., subtract from a polygon, the polygons contained within it AND from the same Inkscape path. This works well for most fonts. You can tell Inkscape to combine multiple polygons into a single path by selecting the polygons and then using "Path > Combine". (You do not need to do this for text converted to a path: Inkscape already does the proper combining.) 15 June 2012: Corrected Windows issue with handling of Unix-style file paths.

Downloading Download the paths2openscad-2.zip file from this page. After unzipping that archive, you should have two files: paths2openscad.py and paths2openscad.inx . The paths2openscad.zip file is the original release of the extension. It has been superseded by paths2openscad-2.zip. Installing Once you have downloaded paths2openscad.zip, open the zip file and place its contents in your local Inkscape extension folder, ~/.config/inkscape/extensions/ on Linux and OS X. On Windows systems, you can place them directly into the Inkscape extension directory. For example, if Inkscape is installed in C:/Program Files/Inkscape then the extension directory will be C:/Program Files/Inkscape/share/extensions. Once you have placed the two files in the proper directory, exit and then restart Inkscape. The extension should appear under the "Extensions > Generate from Path" menu as "Paths to OpenSCAD". Using To use the extension,

  • You may find it helpful to set your document units to millimeters and the document dimension to millimeters as well as a reasonable document size (e.g., 100 x 100 mm). Do this with the "File > Document Properties" menu item. The document units is in the upper part of the dialog box while the document dimensions are near the bottom of that same box.

  • To see what the extension sees, set Inkscape's display mode to "outline". This is done with the "Display Mode" item of the "View" menu.

  • Next ensure that within Inkscape, the desired objects have been converted to paths. Use the "Path > Object to Path" menu item to convert objects such as text to paths.

  • Select the desired objects to generate an OpenSCAD program for. If you wish to generate a program for the entire document, then select nothing (i.e., "Edit > Deselect").

  • From the "Extensions" menu, select "Generate from Path > Paths to OpenSCAD".

  • In the dialog window which appears, enter the name of the output file to generate. (Windows users: the "~" notation indicates that the file goes into your "Document and Settings" folder.) You can also enter a extrusion height and a smoothing parameter. For most purposes, a smoothing parameter of 0.2 is sufficient. If your paths have lots of tight, twisty curves which are described using arcs, circles, ellipses, or other SVG elements which aren't collections of straight line segments, then you may want to use a smaller value.

  • Click the "Apply" button. A pop-up window will appear while the extension is running and will then disappear when it is done running. After the extension is done running, you can click the "Close" button to dismiss the extension's dialog window. If an error occurs, you will see an error window appear when the extension is running.

  • From OpenSCAD, open the output file you generated with the extension and render it.
    • Limitations If you wish to build solids involving subtracting one polygon from another, be sure to combine the two polygons into a single path: select the polygons and then combine them with "Path > Combine". Only a single level of nesting is handled at present. You do not need to do this for text converted to a path: Inkscape already does the proper combining. I have seen a few complex, but legitimate polygons, compile and render with F5 but not with F6 in OpenSCAD. They instead trigger some internal error detection code in OpenSCAD. Notes The sample .svg, .stl, and .scad files serve as examples: you do not need to download them to use this Inkscape extension. You only need the .zip file.

It may be that Inkscape puts the document name
&
amp; path into the document. If so, then I can grab it and use it. Note that the extension's dialog box itself cannot do any extension specific processing. The dialog is described via a static XML document which Inkscape loads when it starts running and then the main Inkscape process builds the dialog from that XML description. No system whereby code running with/for the dialog can be specified. Thus, it's not possible to within the dialog to present a document specific file name. Would have to be a check box along the lines of "save the file with a .scad extension in the same folder as the source document".

title: Sliding Y-Endstop Mount for Prusa i3

description.text:
This sliding Y-endstop is attached to the rear (or front) short threaded rods of the Prusa i3 type 3D printers. The endstop mount consists of a fixed base and a sliding arm onto which the endstop switch is attached. The diameter and the spacing of the rods, as well as the length of the slide and the position of the switch (horizontal or vertical) are all parametrized. The endstop can be mounted without disassembling the rods. It is first "clicked" into the lower short threaded rod and then rotated along the circular cavity to "click" into
the upper rod. The endstop holder holds quite firmly on its own. But for an firmer hold, it can be clamped between two screw nuts - but then you need to disassemble the Y-frame to insert the additional nuts :( . The switch plate has screw holes that fit the standard 20x6mm micro-switches which have screw holes which are spaced by 9.5mm. I found it easiest to extend the 2mm holes with a 2.5mm drill bit and then cut an M3 thread into them (using an M3 tap or just a clean cut M3 screw). The SCAD file is fully parametrized. STL files are provided for 8mm short threaded rods with 20mm rod distance (center-to-center), as well as for 10mm threaded rods with 22mm rod distance. STL files for sliding arms of various lengths and different orientation are also provided. The slide arms are compatible with those of my other endstops, so STL files for further arm variations can also be downloaded from here. Update 2014-11-18: I have now uploaded one more STL file which has the slide cage offset by 10mm (xoff=10 in the SCAD file). This version is useful when the endstop position is to be directly above the threaded rods, as is shown on the 3rd photo. Other than the initial version, this version doesn't have a "dead spot" above the rod, but the endstop switch can be at any location in front or behind the rear rods that is within reach of the slid arm. Near the rod, it might be necessary to rotate the endstop holder by 180 degrees. Update 2015-12-13: I have now uploaded two more STL files in which the slide case is lowered by 4mm and pushed sideways out of the rod area. This version might be useful for printers that have a very low printing platform.

Changing from xoff / yoff to xoff=16 and yoff=-4  will lower the base by 4mm, which is probably the maximum possible.

title: Camper 12v to USB charger box (phone charger)

description.text: I recently bought an older camper and we often go boondock camping (camping with no hookups). I wanted to add an option to charge anything via a USB connection off of the campers battery. I wanted something sleek but functional. I built a 2 part box that screws to the underside of the cabinets. I found a 2 plug 12v usb plug with a built in voltage meter on amazon (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01M0GR0FQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) and i added a hole for a 12v push button switch since the voltage readout would always be on if power is supplied to the unit. I also added a place to put in a blade fuse for added protection for the items plugged into the unit

Monoprice select mini

title: Raspberry pi Camera+Weather station
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This housing is for a raspberry pi, a pi camera and a DHT-11 temp/humidity sensor, and potentially space for more weather related accessories. The case is designed to only accept a single ethernet cable, using either a PiPoE hat or a passive PoE splitter for short runs, or an active poe setup for long runs. The mount is designed to fit Raspberry Pi B+'s , can easily be modified for other pi's.

After printed, you will need to coat the prints exterior in some form of lacquer or resin coating to make sure the inside stays dry if this is placed outside.

You will also need to add a piece of very thing clear plastic over the lens or some other similar method to keep water from intruding into the lens, possibly silicone around the lens as well.

The mounting bracket at the bottom can accept a 1/4 inch by 5/8 inch stud , i.e. a typical camera mounting bracket.

You will need 4 M5x10 SHCS to assemble the housing. Silicone waterproofing can be added in the groove that follows the inner channel of the lid.

Supplies

Passive PoE https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01HMNJHII

M5x10 SCHS https://www.amazon.com/dp/B011BNVPM6

Polyurethane https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000C02AO2/

description.text:
PTFE teflon: 30mm long, 4mm wide and 2mm of inside diameter.

Tired of your PTFE getting stuck with PLA?

Try this solution:
-Put a little water in a glass cup inside the microwave and barely boil the water.
-Insert the blocked PTFE in the water for a few seconds.
-With caution grab the hot PTFE and insert it into the Cleaner.
-Turn the screw until the PLA exits from the bottom of the device.

Works for me. Why Im the first one making this contraption?

description.text:
Micro-compact enclosure for RileyLink, a Bluetooth bridge so that an iPhone can talk to a Medtronic insulin pump using the Loop app:

https://getrileylink.org/

This enclosure is designed to be as small as possible, and to have the antenna visible for the best possible range.

Dimensions: 34x16x56mm.

You can now buy this professionally printed on high-end printers:

https://www.shapeways.com/product/DKKDJSKN5/rileylinkcasetop-09?optionId=63471448
https://www.shapeways.com/product/SGYJ37RJE/rileylinkcasebottom-09?optionId=63471468

Assembly video: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=KbGKFi2bfgE

For flush mounting, the cover is best secured with an M2-0.4 flat-head screw of between 6mm and 12mm in length..

Note that the battery wires should go through the small cutout in the edge of the board.

Once the cover is in place, start inserting the screw. Before the final turn of the screwdriver, press down on the top to seat it. Be very careful to not make the screw too tight, as it may strip the plastic easily.

description.text:
Short run video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K17ALo4rEuw

Only the second run, getting the hang of steering. This is not full throttle as I'm still learning to keep it going straight.

Another favorite toy of mine was the Typhoon hovercraft from Tyco. Here is my version.

You will need:
2 x 2205-2300 motors
2 x 5" props
1 airplane esc forward only
1 esc forward/reverse
3 channel RC receiver
RC radio
battery - I used Turnigy 3s 1300. Room is tight, needs to be small.
2 x wire coat hangers
Rip stop nylon
Plenty of 3mm screws
Epoxy

Printer:

Flashforge Inventor

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

I printed the parts in the orientation that needed the least amount of supports. Some of the thin panels were printed vertically and for those I used rafts.

Clean and glue pieces as needed.

I put a tube on the inside of the skirt at the top and bottom that is big enough for a coat hanger. I shaped coat hanger to match the channel on the bottom skirt attachment and another to match the inside edge of the outer body of the craft. I ran these hanger wires through the tubes in the skirt and used the panels to clamp them in place. This leaves the skirt easy to remove with screws should it need replaced or changed.

title: Skippy's Pop Bottle Bird Feeder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A beautiful yet simple bird feeder that can be printed on a small 120mm print bed with no supports.

Please Respect the CC Licence These are not to be built and sold for personal gain. Greed is humanities greatest weakness.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I highly recommend printing in ABS and not PLA, unless you know it'll be in the shade all the time. PLA will warp in the heat.

Update: I recommend using a skirt attached to the butterfly part as there isn't much surface area for it to adhere to. I have added the small parts file as separate parts files for anyone having issues.

If anyone has any problems just let me know. I have made 5 of these so far with no real issues other then layer splitting. But thats a lack of experience issue. lol.

String

The string that threads the top and bottom together can be threaded in different ways. The holes are a tight 1/4 inch. I recommend using an elastic/bungie cord type string. This way the roof can just stretch off the bottle for simple refilling of the feeder. The bottom of the bottle can be cut off foe easy top-ups or just leave it as is and replace the bottle with a full one when feeder is empty.

The string can be bought at the hardware, craft store store or here on amazon in a large verity of colours.

https://www.amazon.ca/Paracord-Planet-3-2mm-Various-Colors/dp/B00OD5JH84/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1502606362&sr=8-2&keywords=elastic+cord

Image from Amazon site Spring Loaded Butterfly Cinch

I was just going to crimp the bungie string together but I wanted something unique and also adjustable to different bottles. So this is what I came up with. Assembly instructions are as follows.

Remove spring from a dead pen. Why waste a perfectly good pen. Cut spring in half. Drop each spring half in the square holes on the butterfly cinch. Insert the other half into the body. Thread string through to desired length.

If you want it done rite, then do it yourself ! 
 I do bird photography as one of my many hobbies. I have feeders that I bought and hung in the parks to attract the wildlife. But recently they have been going missing.

So I set out to find a small bird feeder STL to download and just print as I needed them. Everything I found was just not to my liking or just too dam big to print with my little 120mm square printer.

That's when I started the project of my custom bird feeder. It began with the pop bottle threads that I have shared for other builder to build from. I kept in mind as I was modelling it to use minimal to zero supports. Then 2 months and three different prototypes later I created "Skippy's Pop Bottle Bird Feeder"

My only problem now is it's too cool. I don't want to leave these in the park because they'll definitely get stolen.

Thank You And Enjoy! Skippy.

title: Filament Spool Holder with a couple mods

description.text:
Not what I really consider a remix since I just modded a few things

  1. Added 2mm height to the studs the bearings go on so there is more material holding the bearings when the studs are melted and squished.
  2. Added a 0.18mm high (1 layer) flat area to the end of the screw to act as a brim so everything can be printed together easily. Naturally it has to be trimmed off after printing to assemble the screw and knob.
  3. Flipped the "slider" 180 degrees so it's oriented to go on the build plate by default.

The knob was not modified at all.

Be sure you put the screw in the "base" before gluing the knob on it.

Printer:

Bibo 2 Touch

No

author: stuart2011

description.text: I made these for Jason 10 x 50 mm Empire binoculars. They fit binocular lenses that are about 63 mm O.D.. Print two sets. Rough cut a piece of solar eclipse filter material for one of the rings. Put several small pieces of double sided tape on one side of the ring. Stick the ring to the filter material. Use a small scissors or razor sharp knife to trim around the outside of the ring. Put several more small pieces of double sided tape around the edge of the filter material. Push the ring, tape, filter material combo into the large housing. Repeat with the other side. The filter material should be sandwiched between the ring and the inside of the housing. Waves and minor wrinkles are OK, creases or holes are not OK.

This is the Dwarven Helmet from The Elder Scrolls V Skyrim. This helmet was a request from one of my patrons. If you like to make a request please become a member of my patreon page. I get too many requests on here Thingiverse to fill them all.

https://www.patreon.com/user?u=4430621

This helmet is sized to fit an adult male. please check pdf file for measurements. units are in millimeters.

Note : The battle damaged helmet does have small holes in the helmet which were intentional. They are very small and can be filled if you wanted to. If you do not like extra holes please stick to the clean version. Also do not scale down the damaged version. This will cause more holes to form. It can be scaled up. The clean version is safe to scale down or up.

title: Health Club and Spa - HO scale

description.text:
Your support can help me to create and release more new designs.
Become a Patron!
Thank you.

If you are British, you are probably familiar with the Bannantyne chain of Health Clubs. I liked the sloping design of the roof, and used their buildings as inspiration for this design
It has "Your Name Here" on the front of the building...you should, of course, change this to the name YOU want to use. So you'll need to be able to edit the stl file. (I can do it for you if you ask nicely. :)
It is in HO scale, and measures 230mm long x 188mm wide x 106mm tall.
Oh...pool included. :)

Notes:

You will need to print the roof on its side, I would recommend a raft to stop it getting knocked over. You could lay it down, if you don't mind spending hours cleaning up the support material residue.
I would also recommend printing all the windows and doors at 98% ... it just makes them easier to fit in the holes without the need for sanding, when assembling

Approximately 20 hours printing time...according to Cura, so its very approximate lol

author: nzfreemo

print_settings.Notes:: Works best at 0.2 mm layer height. Also, be sure to have a decent amount of infill overlap for the red, black and orange layers to avoid gaps in your fill!

description.text:
A multi-color print that creates the Hokie bird (Virginia Tech's Mascot) when 3D printed.
This is a 4-color print, that requires white, red/maroon, black, and orange filament to print.

LAYER HEIGHT AND COLOR:
0 - 2.0 mm: WHITE
2.0 - 2.4 mm: RED/MAROON
2.4 - 2.8 mm: BLACK
2.8 - 3.2 mm: ORANGE

I used the "Variable Settings Wizard" that was added in Simplify3D version 4.0 to split the model at the correct heights (2.0, 2.4, and 2.8). After splitting the model, I adjusted the settings in each process to match what I desired. Next, I printed the model one process at a time, changing the filament color between each process change.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Works best at 0.2 mm layer height. Also, be sure to have a decent amount of infill overlap for the red, black and orange layers to avoid gaps in your fill!

1. Create Vector

I first opened up Adobe Illustrator and placed an image of the Hokie bird as a template.

I then used the pen tool to trace the image. After doing so, I exported my tracing as a DXF.

2. SolidWorks

I extruded a circle in SolidWorks. Then, I selected the front face and imported my DXF. Then, I extruded each color at different amounts. Since I normally print at 0.2 mm layer height, I used 0.4 mm intervals to separate each color.
When I choose the order of the colors, I think about the way it will feel and how much it is used in the design. i know that most of the logo is red, so that is the first, followed by black then orange. Normally, I would put black on top, but then the orange would show up on the side where all the outlines are as viewed at an angle.

title: Calibration Block with Countersunk Hole and Slot

description.text: Calibration Block with Countersunk Hole and Slot to catch problems with elements inside perimeter of object.

I took the 20mm block from Spacexula's calibration set and added a countersunk screw hole for a M3 socket-head screw, and a slot for a M3 nut to be able to check my bots ability to accuratly do inside holes and slots in an object.
Edit: (from algspd's comments below, I updated the object to use values that should produce a snug fit, the old values were the nominal diameters for an M3 socket-head screw)
The head diameter is 5.89mm and the shaft diameter is 3.06mm, this should produce a snug fit. I created this calibration block to test the accuracy of the inside diameter of a hole on a Printrbot Plus, from a SketchUp file.

author: TechnoSwiss

description.text: for anet a8 only rod diameter is 8mm. use M4*8 Screw to lock Z rod.

comments.text:
In no way am I being disrespectful to the creator at all. But I fail to see how this is going to eliminate the all to know dreaded Z-Wobble.
I feel that the smooth rods are not the problem, but the leadscrews are the problem with Z-Wobble. If your leadscrews are not perfectly straight and are not installed perfectly into couplers along with having the exact length of X-Axis belt with the perfect amount of tension, then you are gping to get Z-Wobble. The only way to truly get rid of Z-Wobble is to use MGN12 linear rails for your Z-Axis, but even then its hard to get them to work perfectly. Z-Wobble is a huge problem that we all face.
comments.author: shawnb03

comments.text:
yes you are right there many reason for z-wobble, but for some anet a8 the smooth rod are loose that can amplify z-wobble.
this design eliminate that movement of the smooth rod. like you said even MGN 12 linear rails is not perfect. it is a process of elimination, eliminating one problem can get you closer to solving z-wobble. i have some modification in my anet a8 including the lead screw but i am still using factory z-rod and still achieve perfect print. i have never posted my lead screw design as different printer has different tolerance.

remixed_from.author: graham01
remixed_from.title: CR-10 3 in 1 Extruder Cover and Filament Guide

description.text:
Overview:

I designed a Bracket to hold a filament run-out sensor i bought off ebay.
When the filament runs out, in this order it will:

  1. Pause the print
  2. retract filament to stop oozing,
  3. move the head away to allow filament change
  4. resume back where it initially stopped.
Properties:
  • It slips over the Extruder, and also has a cable holder integrated.
  • The design allows it so you can use a small amount of PTFE tube to make it easier for the filament to guide into the extruder motor.
  • Sensor Light up green when there is filament detected
You Will Need:

-Sensor:
AliExpress: https://goo.gl/FutpoC

-Connectors for Raspberry pi:
http://r.ebay.com/9g8yce

-RaspberryPi running Octoprint

Setup Steps:

  1. print out Filament Sensor and Lid
  2. Install Sensor inside housing (will be a tight fit)
  3. Wire up Sensor to Raspberry Pi. ( follow tutorial if stuck https://youtu.be/j7JfQXTf16U)
  4. Install "Filament Sensor Reloaded" plugin on Octopi
Stock Firmware:
  • Set Pin: 7
  • Debounce Time: 400ms

  • Switch type: Normally Open
    -Board Pin Mode: Board Mode
    Pause Print When Out of Fliament : (Tick)

    Now Edit Pause and Resume GCode (refer to photos below)

Firmware 1.10+

(Currently seems firmware is ignoring M600 L0, so please follow stock firmware setup if you manage to figure out how to stop m600 retracting the filament. please let me know in the comments)

  • Set Pin: 7
  • Debounce Time: 400ms
  • Switch type: Normally Open
    -Board Pin Mode: Board Mode
    -Out of Filament GCODE: M600 E-5 L0 X10 Y10 Z5
    Pause Print When Out of Fliament : (No Tick)
updates:

(D,M,Y)

14/08/2017: Edited G-code pause function as the steppers were disabling after 60 seconds of the filament running out which led to printer loosing its coordinates. Now should stay on for 6 hours

14/08/2017: Better Lid design and better model design with smaller extruder cover hole, there should be no printing issues now.

27/08/2017: Added a dust cover for the extruder opening

up-coming:
  • updated Gcode
  • better lid design
  • fixed model hollow slicing issues
  • Printing without supports

Printer:

Creality Cr-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10% - 20%

Notes:

Supports settings:
Support pillar resolution: 2.5mm
Max overhang angle: 65 Degrees.

PRINT:
Make sure theres no supports generated inside the Holes, unless your comfortable
clearing the holes

The Lid is required to keep the filament and the switch in the right position

Octoprint Pause / Resume Settings (credit: https://gist.github.com/foosel/1c09e269b1c0bb7a471c20eef50c8d3e)

After Print job is paused:

{% if pause_position.x is not none %}
; relative XYZE
G91
M83

; retract filament, move Z slightly upwards
G1 E-10 F6750
G1 Z+5

; absolute XYZE
M82
G90

; move to a safe rest position, adjust as necessary
G1 X0 Y0
M18 S21600
{% endif %}

Before print job is resumed:

{% if pause_position.x is not none %}
; relative extruder
M83

; prime nozzle
G1 E-5 F4500
G1 E5 F4500
G1 E10 F4500

; absolute E
M82

; absolute XYZ
G90

; reset E
G92 E{{ pause_position.e }}

; move back to pause position XYZ
G1 X{{ pause_position.x }} Y{{ pause_position.y }} Z{{ pause_position.z }} F4500

; reset to feed rate before pause if available
{% if pause_position.f is not none %}G1 F{{ pause_position.f }}{% endif %}
{% endif %}

description.text:
The enochian alphabet typewriter key set provides a set of strike-plates you can glue onto the hammers of a typewriter to convert you typewriter to output this alphabet.

Enochian is a name often applied to an occult or angelic language recorded in the private journals of John Dee and his colleague Edward Kelley in late 16th-century England.[3] Kelley was a spirit medium who worked with Dee in his magical investigations. The men claimed that the language was revealed to them by the Enochian angels.

This project was completed as part of the 2017 GISHWHES event, a scavenger hunt loosely affiliated with the US television show Supernatural, which features fictional use of the enochian alphabet.

author: DirtyPandaBoi

description.text:
These bearing presses make it easy to properly seat your v-wheel or mini v-wheel bearings.

Wheel assembly video: https://youtu.be/i_j12lvyCpI

  1. Put a bearing on to the peg.
  2. Put the washer on to the peg.
  3. Press the wheel down on the bearing. (If the wheel doesn't slide on to the bearing easily then try step 5 below.)
  4. Press in the second bearing.
  5. Flip the whole assembly over on a hard smooth surface and press down on the bearing with your pam, elbow, foot or whatever.

No more sore fingers or fiddling to line things up :)

Please share your makes!

Get OpenBuilds compatible v-wheels and bearings in red or blue! https://3dvice.co

No

100%

title: Creality Ender-4 E3D Titan Aero mount

description.text:
Bracket to mount an E3D Titan Aero on a Creality Ender-4. It uses stock screws/bolts, allows for the eccentric to be adjusted, and mounts the Titan Aero facing forward to it's (IMO) easier to work on/with.

I recommend ABS or PETG with 3 perimeters and 40% infill. Prints without supports.

This requires using a pancake stepper.

comments.text: I believe this would also be the exact same for the Tronxy X5S printer as it is very similiar design as the Ender 4.  It is a single 2020 upper bar that moves front to back on the Y axis and is belt driven left to right on the X axis. Point is you may want to add Tronxy X5S to your description to help folks find your "thing"  Nice job

description.text:
I've been getting ready to view and photograph the upcoming US total solar eclipse. This is a simple slide-on ring for retaining solar filter film on a pair of binoculars. It was designed to work on a pair of Bushnell 10x32 binoculars which have a 42mm diameter at the front lens tube. This could be made to work on other binoculars simply by scaling in X and Y to account for differing diameters.

Print two copies, face down on the bed as shown.

To assemble, carefully cut a piece of certified solar filter film large enough to fully cover the front lens element. Place it on top of the lens tube, then slide the retaining ring on to hold it in place. On my print, it's a decent friction fit, but if the binoculars are going to be handled a lot and you want to make sure it stays on, wrap some gaffers tape around it and you'll be set.

D-Bot

title: Solar Filter Holder for Nikon AF-S DX 55-300 Lens

description.text:
With the US total eclipse coming up, I've been getting ready to view and photograph it. This is a snap-on solar filter holder for the Nikon AF-S DX 55-300mm f/4.5-5.6 ED VR lens. It snaps on in place of the HB-57 lens hood.

Print one of each part, face-down as shown.

To assemble, cut a piece of certified solar filter film just smaller than the inner/base piece. Place the film on the base piece, then slide the cap piece on top to retain the film. On my print, it's a nice friction fit, but you might want a drop of glue to hold it together if it's looser. It should snap on and off fairly easily, especially if you squeeze on the side opposite the little tabs which will spread it a little.

Note: the version shown in my photos was my first design that was longer than necessary. It limited how much you could retract the lens, so I shortened it some but haven't reprinted it yet.

D-Bot

title: CR-10 3 in 1 Extruder Cover and Filament Guide with Window

description.text: I really like the original model, great execution of a good idea. However, I like to see if my idler bearing on the extruder is still spinning or if I got another clog and the gear is cutting a divot in the filament again. So I put an oval window to have a look-see.

comments.text:
Hey mate, i like your design however it doesnt fit the CR-10S extruder, as the wheel release handle to pass the filament through to the PTFE tube is too big and therefore doesnt fit in your cover cut out.
Im assuming the CR-10 has a smaller handle that utilises a smaller cut out as per your design.
Any chance of making an amendment for a CR-10s?
comments.author: Clot

comments.text: Hi there, just printed this but the new CR 10S comes with a filament sensor and this means your filament guide is out of line with the sensor exit. Impossible to pass the filament through the sensor and through this. Also the filament sensor guides the filament as to not allow contact with the z axis. I removed part of this object (the filament guide) but still use the rest as it is a good way to hold the cable.

print_settings.Notes:: 3mm Brim

description.text:
This is a redesign of the Gyro Air made by Dalpek. I attempted to print his and noticed a few areas that can be improved. I recommend slow print speeds, part cooling fan on 100%, no support material if your printer can handle it, and a 3mm brim. I printed it at 250um (0.25mm) layer height.
Print time is shorter, less material, better rotation and easier to assemble.

Included is also a stand so that you can rest it and spin it one handedly. I recommend normal print speeds. I printed it at 250um (0.25mm) layer height.

Let me know what you think, if you have any thoughts on design improvements please suggest and I will make the appropriate changes. If you would like the stand customized comment with your email, I will personally send the .STL with your customization done.

And due to popular demand I have included a smaller model as well. I am not certain if it will print well. Enjoy!

Printer:

Anycubic i3 Mega

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

250um

Infill:

100% (20% for stand)

Notes:

Special notes for printing the Gyrosphere

  • 3mm Brim
  • slow print speed
  • part cooling fan 100%

Post Processing and Display

Here is how I make it look good.

Since there are big overhangs, bridging defects occur, with a pair of tweezers remove all of the un-bonded layers of plastic, then lightly sand away the rough edges with any sandpaper.

Depending on the resolution of your printer you may need to open the holes of the pocket a tiny bit. To do this you'll need a lighter and a thin pointy object, I used a paperclip. Heat the paperclip and then poke the hole applying some pressure and rotating gently.

I spray painted mine silver, which may have added a 5-15 um more length to the pins, it also created a smoother surface for them to rotate freely. If you need, add a drop of oil to the pin and sockets, I did this by daubing a toothpick into some oil and transferring it onto the joint.

comments.text: I’ve printed 4 of this model myself, one for every member of my family who wants one. No failures (even after being dropped a few times). Meanwhile on the first time I printed the Gyro Air it broke immediately. In my model I’ve accounted for this by making the walls much thinner. Unintuitively, the thin frame allows it to be flexible enough to avoid breaking on impact, instead of being overly fragile.

title: Protective Cover for FlexRC Lady-Owl Quadcopter Frame

description.text: Hello, here's a neat cover for the FlexRC lady owl frame. I bought the quadcopter frame from FlexRC.com. It comes with the carbon-fiber X plate, some nylon spacers, nylon screws and the flexible prop-guard halo. However, the purchase does not provide a cover or a mount for the camera / VTX so I printed my own cover to protect the Flight-controller, it also allows mounting the VTX on its under-side. I also printed my own 7-deg camera mount for indoor FPV flight. This is truly an "unbreakable" quad, it had taken a few hard crashes and no damage at all! Watch the video of my setup at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VnU0titSfRM

print_settings.Notes:: http://a.co/hl0io3x

description.text:
I needed some battery holders for my electronics projects but I did not have any of the connectors which other battery holders such as https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456900 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:331394 use and so I decided to CAD battery holders that use strips of tin (or aluminum but I don't know how you'd solder wires onto that) as contacts for the battery. This is the result.

If you need to use the battery holder for a battery type that isn't included, use Meshmixer to change the scales. Only downside is the ends will be either shrunken or enlarged, reducing the flexibility or the durability of the final product.

Open up Meshmixer > import 'battery holder AA.stl' > edit > transform > uncheck uniform scale option > divide your battery's diameter by 14 and enter the result into the Z and Y axis scale > divide the height of your battery by 50 and enter the result into the X axis scale > export your new battery holder

title: Mini Rack Mounted Dual RPI/Odroid C1+ Case with Integrated Screen
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
im considering time lapseing all of my prints that i am actually home for from now on it seems fun to watch in the end... heres my first one ...

pretty cool i think.

ok now for what this is. This is another addition to my mini rack mount system. it is an enclosure for 1 or 2 RPI B+ or 1 or 2 Odroid C1+ (and if you dont know what that is it is the board that works like a RPI b+ but then in the end stomps its ass it even has an ADC on top of the extra power) IN my case i have an Odroid (purchased after my RPI) and my original/first RPI B+. it has a mount on the side for a single 40MM fan and vents in the lid becasue well heat rises. the front panel is embossed with the Cyberdyne systems skynet logo becasue my buddy is always joking i am building sky net.. (he doesnt understand computers or electronics, it literally scares him.) the skull in the middle of the logo has 2 5mm holes for placing status leds (one for each pi) i recommend bicolor or tricolor leds (mine happen to be left over common anode RGB leds. in the pictures i have up i havent mounted the handles onto the case but they also go on the front. the front is also equipped with a ili9341 2.2 inch touch screen and i may be dreaming but somehow i will get the full functionality out of it, or worst case scenario i will turn it into a menu driven system with touch... either way it ups the cool factor. on the back panel there are well placed holes for the computers as well as 17 holes for USB ports...

"Gee why all the usb ports?"

becasue im pretty sure at this time a "USB" port is the most commonly used 4 pin connector on the face of the planet. that makes them cheap, their size makes them convient to place just about every where and the connection is pretty resiliant, which if you are a maker like me with about 10lbs of them laying aorund you try to use them for anything but their original intent, thus these 14 usb are capable of exporting from this case 56 individual signal lines, that means 7 of them can put all the connections from a RPI out side the box, from there i take them into a jumper configurable patch panel (kinda like a server room would) and then i move those configured signal lines to the periferial they go to, making it flexible and pretty convient.. i should have the patch panel design up here in the up comming week, provided i dont run out of plastic. (im at a half a roll with a 103gram print running .. lol ... i hope i get all this done, the print i am running now is the arduino mega case. ) basically in the back of my rack will be a patch panel for power and a patch panel for the rpi/odroid and 3 patch panels for the Arduino mega(s)

scale is either .1 or 100 depending on your slicer. the front bezel is 180MM

title: Wanhao D6/Monoprice Ultimate - 50x15mm blower duct - revision 3

description.text:
This is an improved cooling solution for a Wanhao Duplicator 6 (D6) / Monoprice Ultimate. This blower duct is small and simple: it channels the airflow to a smaller cross-section to increase the air speed, and directs the focused airflow at the extrusion point while avoiding cooling of the whole metal block (and thus avoiding bad heating errors).

You will want to slowly ramp up the fan speed, or else you will overcool and force the firmware to terminate the print (respond as though the heating element is broken). For instance, I ramp the fan speed to at least 65%, but over ~14 0.1mm layers -- I tell Cura to ramp the fan speed over 1.5 mm. Then, the printer can handle much faster fan speeds.

Tighten the nuts sufficiently (but not so much to crack the plastic blower casing) to keep the blower from turning. Important: large diameter washers/large diameter nuts prevent the blower case from splitting as you tighten the assembly to fix it in place.
I printed the part so that if air were flowing through it, it would be blowing upward.

I purchased exactly this blower (link below)...it has the proper electrical connector already, runs at the necessary 24V, is rather powerful, is very quiet, and of course is reasonably inexpensive.

http://www.ebay.com/itm/BPB5015M24V-BLOWER-FAN-24V-DC-2P-50mm-15mm-10-wire-2-pins-connector-1pc/281940091393?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

I hope someone else finds this useful and I'll make any improvements until this approach is as good as it can get.

Regarding versions
V1 is no longer posted. The file had a few small annoyances that showed up in the prints.
V2 is the simple duct, designed so that there is one bolt to mount the fan to the heat sink.
V3 is V2 plus an extra small arm that attaches to the heat sink in an additional location, right above the nozzle. It is still convenient to print. But a word of warning...it is hard to remove the screw -- the factory made them tight. I had to drill mine out and use a replacement screw. In the end, I like the assurance that the fan will not rotate if a single bolt and nuts loosen.

title: CR-10  50 x 15 Double Blower Fan Fang Mount

description.text:
This is remix version of
Imagine That Titian/Atlas, Creality CR-10, Afinibot A31 Print Cooling by RebelRousingProps. Here are improvement I've made.

  1. The original one actually doesn't accept my 50 x15 mm part fan, because its actual thickness is 15.6. So I enlarge the mounting hole to fit the part fan.

  2. The original design also make the bowden clamp at the heatbreak side slightly bended to the front because there's no room for it. And I'm afraid this might affect the nozle system perpendicularity so I correct this in the design.

  3. For the heat break fan I redesign the screw hole that attach the bracket to heatbreak. Original design needs longer screw. I used stock screw and make the attachment point thinner.

I print the double blower bracket with the flat side on the bed. And for the heatbreak fan bracket I print it standing on the flat side like in the picture/
Be inform that I still use stock hotend.

Updated :
Added bed levelling sensor mount version

description.text:
Designed for a DIY composting toilet, this urine diverter lets you redirect your urine to be used as fertiliser for your garden. It is designed to be placed underneath the toilet seat of the composting toilet, with a hose connected to the end which outputs to a container. Fresh urine diluted 1 part per 10 parts water is an excellent source of nitrogen for your garden.The diverter model has been split into two pieces (for smaller print beds) - they can then be glued together using a silicon sealer.

Note: If printing with PLA you may want to coat the final printed product (both halves) in a protective coating to prevent decomposition of the plastic in the long term.

An mic arm addon for K7XX (should also work with some other models) with some degrees of movements.
require 3 or 2 M2 screws and maybe nuts
(2 Screw needed if upward hinge is not used, 6mm M2 if you require no nut and 8mm M2 if you do)
Please note:
It will scratch the plastic where the clip holds on to the headphone. You might be able to get away with it by printing it smaller and breaking away the inner side of the clip before clipping it on, but that will not be as secure.
This will work on either side of the headphone. I suggest to put it on the side with the headset wires and twist the mic wire with the headphone wire so you don't have 2 wires hanging down.
Quick tip, buy cable sleeve and tidy up both cable. see pic

WARNING! DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY AT THE SUN WITH THE NAKED EYE. UNPROTECTED EXPOSURE CAN CAUSE PERMANENT BLINDNESS!! ONLY USE FILTERS RATED FOR VIEWING THE SUN!

USE THIS DESIGN AT YOUR OWN RISK!!

ALRIGHT NOW.. (caps off) Alright, now that is out of the way.

In preparation for what many are calling "the Great American Eclipse" on August, 21, 2017. I decided I would design a more elegant way of securing a solar filter to the front of my scope. It is a simple design that sandwiches a sheet of solar film between two rings and then the assembly is friction fit to the front of the scope.

ADDITIONAL WARNING! Do NOT attempt to point your scope to the sun without the proper filter on the FRONT lens of the scope this may damage the scope or worse your EYES.

Happy and SAFE eclipse viewing everone!

The the two halves are secured together using 2 to 4 screws. ( I used two M3 10mm left over from my 3D printer build) The whole filter assembly fits very snug to the tapered lip on the front of the scope but can be removed with a gentle twist and tug. I cut my solar film to 6.5" x 6.5" and trimmed the corners and this filled the 6" opening on the ring.

I might also suggest sandwiching the solar film between glass or some clear rigid plastic to protect the film from accidental damage.

The filter film I used for this project.
https://www.amazon.com/Solar-Filter-Telescopes-Binoculars-Cameras/dp/B00DS7S52W/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1502605907&sr=8-3&keywords=solar+film

für Anet A8 eine LED-Lichtleiste die oben an den Anet A8 eingeklemmt wird.

The voltage supply for the LED light comes from the power supply of the Anet A8.

remixed_from.author: sailorpete
remixed_from.title: Root 2 CNC multitool router 3D printed parts

description.text:
By now you know the ROOT range of cnc's ...but, those of you out there who are like me, and suffer from sausage finger syndrome, know or may have found, or will find, that difficulty when it comes time to deal with the Idler box mounting, positioning and securing.

So what I came up with was a way to get round it. by making a larger base plate that the idler mounts into, then you can drill and secure the now larger surface area with larger nuts and bolts. You still have access to the under side of the box for cabling and whatever you may need it for.

Designed to use the standard bolts from the ROOT build... so M3/4/5 and a couple of washers, nuts and bolts and you are good to go!

Hope this helps those who need it.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

30-40%

Notes:

This is a pretty straight-forward print, lay it flat, face up and print away.

I used PLA at 0.25 layer height at about 210'C and infill is whatever you feel comfortable with , but i wouldn't recommend anything less than 30% do to the load it has to take.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Control Box Air Baffle

description.text:
I recently upgraded my printer to a 120mm fan from the stock 40mm fan. The new fan moves a lot more (about 5 times more) air! This has had the unfortunate effect of cooling the front corner of my print bed, which has caused several prints warp. Not enough to cause a failure, yet, but I don't want to chance it!

I designed the baffle to redirect the air forward. It's a simple design that requires only (4) 11" zip ties to secure it to the control box.

UPDATE 2: Version 2.01
-: Added more space for side diodes
-: added fan 30 x 30mm and thicker cover

After printing version 2 i discovered that the diodes in the sides wont fit so i had to fix this .. now the fan holder plate is thicker screws fit better..
case now is at 40 x 40 ..

Update: version 2.00

After testing the first prototype, i noticed the diodes getting warm so i updated the enclosure to include a 30mm fan to cool them out !

So looking at different posts on forums i came across the stepper motor smoother ! it uses 4 to 8 diodes to silent the stepper motors ..

different boards are out there , but one can simply build it and encase everything in the case i designed !

this Little addon will eliminate those fuzzy line on your prints ...

Parts needed

1N5404 or 1n5408 diodes
12v 30 x 30 fan
2 x 4 pin sockets
piece of wires ..

Instructions

print the stl file
gather the parts and solder them as per schematic
install in case and secure with some hot glue ..
make sure you power the fan from a 12v source.

connect the smoother in series with the stepper motor - ie between the stepper motor and the stepper driver

enjoy

These are back covers for Nema 23 and Nema 24 motors. Features include a wire channel and cover, a mount for a 4 pole ~16mm connector, cover of the rear axle (if present) which keeps it from rubbing on the wires.

The package includes the following motor covers:

Nema 23 (56.4mm motor diameter) e.g. 23H276-28-4B

  • Nema 23 cover with straight connector
  • Nema 23 cover with a 90 degree angle connector
  • Nema 23 cover with a 90 degree angle connector - Large version with more room between end of connector and cap making it easier to screw the connector in

Nema 24 (60mm motor diameter) e.g. 24H290-35-4B

  • Nema 24 cover with straight connector
  • Nema 24 cover with a 90 degree angle connector
  • Nema 24 cover with a 90 degree angle connector - Large version with more room between end of connector and cap making it easier to screw the connector in

The caps are secured to the stepper with 4 M3 screws.

Installation of the connector: fit the cap and route the wires through the connector hole, cut the wires to the correct length (tip: coil the wires inside the cap to get some additional length), remove the cap, route the stepper wires through the connector nut, after that route them through the hole in the cap (from the inside to the outside naturally :-) ) solder them to the connector. Place the nut over the connector hole and screw the connector into the nut (though the hole in the cap).
For the small 90 degree version this can be a bit tricky as you need to ensure that the wires inside do not twist around each other or the connector. Tricky but doable as you only need ~2 turns of the connector for it to sit tight. If you want more room to do that more easily, print the large version.

Have fun.

author: PistonPin

description.text:
• If you made this thing and are happy with it I kindly ask to let me and others know...

I had some heat-cartridges here which I wanted to test some time but never did for
it always daunted me unwrapping all those cables without absolute need of.

So I made this cable-duct which still looks kind of professional (I think at least)
but could be easily opened and the cables removed.

There is need to drill new holes for it, I intentinally did not use the ones already there.
The upper one is directly behind the y-axis driveshaft, for the lower one you would need to
hit the nut again which is hidden in the bottom plate and between back-wall and z-axis motor.
I placed the holes that they are accessible from the front.
Use M3 counter-sunk ones, even for flat heads there is not enough space between wall
and moving platform. And still the holes are directly behind the z-shaft so it will be a bit fiddly, though.

Print as much clips as you see fit for your needs or scale it in the z-axis for complete enclosure...
