title: FESTO cordless drill CDD 12 battery holder

description.text:
This is a replacement LiPo battery holder that can be used in place of the FESTOOL BP12C or BPH12C batteries for the FESTOOL CDD 12 ES or CDD 12 FX cordeless drills.The holder also includes a voltmeter to monitor the battery state and 4 magnetic bit holders.

History

I have used several cordless drills but my favorite is still the FESTOOL CDD12 because of its ergonomic design which I have had for 17 years. I have replaced the batteries several times over the years but, somehow, they do not last as long as the originals.
When it was time for another battery replacement, I decided to convert it to lithium.

Design Considerations

The original batteries were NiCAD's with a nominal voltage of 12V. LiPO's are nominally 3.6V per cell but can go as high as 4.2V. That leaves you with a choice of either 3 of 4 LiPO batteries. I chose to go with the 4 which gives a maximum of 16.8V and a nominal voltage of 14.4V. This is on the high side but I think that the engineer probably used at least 20V components any way and (hopefully) this should be fine.
The easy way to do this is to simply rip out the existing batteries and replace them with LiPo's (they should fit in quite easily since you replace the existing 10 batteries with only 4). but decided against this for the following reasons:

  • you need a spot welder to connect them together (you can solder them but it is not a good idea)
  • you need to add a connector to balance charge the batteries
  • somebody might think that this is a normal NiCAD and place the LiPO's in the NiCAD charger.
  • it is more difficult to replace individual cells
  • you can use your normal LiPo charger
  • you can share the batteries between different devices
    So I opted for standard size 18650 that can fit into a 3D printed battery holder.

    Battery Choice

    18650 LiPo batteries are easy to find. Unfortunately you can not use any 18650's because most of them will not work on a drill due to the high current needed. For a drill you need at least 15A peak and about 5A nominal. There are several different 18650 that meets this requirement, I chose the SAMSUNG INR18650-30Q's. Note that there are a lot of fakes that will not deliver the needed current, so buy from a reputable supplier!

• Main battery holder: 3D printed
  • Release button: 3D printed
  • Release clip catch: cut from 3mm plastic sheet, e.g. Lexan or perspex, about 40x50mm
  • 3x12 mm screws (imperial equivalent or self tapper should work as well)
  • 2x springs about 5mm x 20mm for the release
  • 4x magnets round 5mm diameter and 3-6mm long for the bit holder
  • small volt meter - optional
  • 3x conductors, either copper or preferably nickel coated copper, to inter connect the batteries
  • 20mm double sided tape for attaching the cattery contact on the drill

Print the parts - white is not the best choice but that is what I had. I used PETG with a 0.4mm nozzle at a layer height of 0.2mm and placed the print on its side. You can use ABS as well in which case it might be a better option to place it upright (this will avoid cracking of the ABS).

After printing the parts, cut the plastic sheet which will be part of the release clip to fit into the top of the battery holder as shown in the photos. Take note of the 2 protrusions at the bottom there the springs should fit. Without these the springs do not stay in position. Make sure that the plastic slides smoothly. Place the slider/catch in position and mark the 2 holes. Drill the 2 holes 3mm. Screw it all together.

Cut the copper conductor for the batteries, 2 of about 6.5mm x 50mm and make sure that they can slide into the slots at the bottom of the holder up into the volt meter compartment..
If you want to mount the volt meter, feed the wires through the slots from the inside and solder to the copper conductors. It is also a good idea to place 2 solder blobs on each conductor where the batteries make contact. This will ensure that the battery isolation plastic does not press against the conductor. You might also dome the conductor with a punch at these contact points. Push the conductors all the way into the slots and insert the voltmeter. If the conductors do not stay in position, glue them in position.

The last part is to add a contact on the battery to connect the bottom 2 batteries. This is done as shown in the photo by sticking a conductor below the drill battery contacts with double sided tape. Double or triple fold the ends of the conductors to make sure that they make proper contact with the batteries or add another layer of double sided tape if needed.

It should all work now. Note that the volt meter only measure the voltage across 2 batteries. When full it should indicate about 8-8.4V. I would say that you should not let the batteries discharge to less than 6.5V on the voltmeter. (below about 2.5V per cell you will damage your batteries permanently.)

Warning: There is no protection on these batteries, so you can overheat them and they can catch fire if they are shorted and they can be damaged if you discharge them to low.

3D printed enclosures tend to be really light. You'd better not sneeze or your latest gizmo blows off your desk. The Leadfoot is hollow and can be filled with ballast, such as sand, for added weight. I think this adds an impression of robustness and quality.

The case customizable. See the attached drawing. Of course, the dimensions of the PCB (width, depth, thickness and corner radius) can be altered. Other interesting options are supporting ledgers and spacers. Possible mounting holes can be fastened using "pegs" or screws (drilled spacers) with or without holes for hex nuts.

The two uploaded STL files are:

  • A 80x50mm leadfoot with no customization. It uses support ledgers, drilled spacers and M2.5 hex nuts.
  • A 1x1.5" enclosure with pegs for the mounting holes. Fits an Adafruit Huzzah breakout perfectly, as shown in the picture.

Some hints for mounting:

  • Fill the ballast with a small funnel (I used this one). Plug the hole with glue.
  • The holes for the hex nuts form overhangs, which might cause a bit of threading. Clear with a sharp pin. Before mounting the PCB, fasten the nuts by tightening them with a screw from the top. The fit is so tight they will stay foot.

Happy tweaking, knock yourself out!

title: Remixed X210 body with camera guard and 45 deg SMA mount

description.text:
This is a remixed, light-weight version of the nice Realacc X210 (Standard) body kit by westers47. I redrew everything except the front part of the body to save some weight. The sides are non-structural and their only function if to protect wires and to keep everything clean and organized. Like in the original design, I made the sides curved to allow easy maintenance and access to USB. I also moved the small protrusions at the front of the original body design to the bottom of the camera guard. This allows easy printing of the body upside down with only some supports for the LED mount.

I also combined this model with the nice 45 degree SMA mount created by earlynerd. Together with the included additional supports, this mount has just the right amount of flex to protect your antenna in heavy landings. The supports attached above the SMA connector also take some strain away from the connector itself. Print it with semi-rigid TPU/TPE filament (Semiflex, Cheetah) for best durability and antenna protection.

Using these body parts does not require any changes to the original X210 frame. The total weight of all TPU parts is around 15 grams.

The antenna supports can be easily printed on their side with no supports.

description.text:
Passive amplification is amazing for what it can do to the audio from a tinny little speaker. The iPhone7 adds a stereo speaker at the top of the phone face alongside the previous speaker on the bottom of the phone. This passive amplifier has pickups in both locations to reproduce the stereo sound and double the amplification.

Also, many amplifiers are quite tinny in their amplification because they expand the cone very quickly. This amplifier is all about length, the pathway for each high band amplifier is 200mm long and expands 8x over this length.

The mid and low-band frequencies are treated to a 400mm path expanding 5x over that path. The lower expansion over a longer distance helps the low band amplify better.

While not the same quality as a good Bluetooth speaker, it sure is a lot more fun to build!

There's a lot of overhangs, but all the big ones have been accommodated so don't print with any supports.
There is a support built into the model for the impossible overhang of the face mounted speaker. This is trimmed away before use.

This was done completely in OpenSCAD. However, if you want to open this file, be warned it takes a long time compile. The final render of this model took 1h30m on my system. To speed up any design changes, open the file and scroll towards the bottom, there are 5 lines that are indicated "remove for F5 support", comment these lines out and the model will render without the interior cones and without the automatically generated support structures. Add these line back in and press F6 to wait for an hours long render.

There are two small rectangles on either side of the model, these are there to make sure that the 6" print width of many printers will be able to print this model once the first layer is done and not wait until many hours into the print. Throw them away after build.

The spline distance is borrowed from the bezier.scad file which is included as a download. It is also available as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8443.

The 1958 FIFA World Cup championship in football was held
in Sweden Stockholm Rasunda. Brazil won the
final against Sweden 5-2
A Swedish petroleum companie gave out this ball in a cup, as a
advertising gadgetst during the football world cup 1958. Felt like it was a perfect thing to print out on the 3D printer 56 years later.
A simple thing that you can have fun with.
Especially as it's World Cup 2014 take place in Brazil this summer. But without Sweden this time. It is also an excellent thing to give away as a gift. You can print labels to paste around the cup.
For example, company logo, your website or whatever you want. Feel free to change this,it is perhaps an idea / inspiration for something else with this ball cup game.. I just wanted to share the idea. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P7WJzJpReDA

The ball can be printed as a solid ball or in two halves and glued together.
you have to drill a hole in the bottom of the cup.
To get a complete unit you need about 40cm long piece of string. a knot in the bottom of the cup and tie the ball on the string. Then it's just trying to get the ball into the cup, best of 10 maybe.
Good luck if you want to make your own, so are the dimensions of the cup.
23mm in diameter and 31mm high. thickness is 1.5 to 2mm
and the ball is 17mm in diameter

author: Robchiks

description.text:
I needed a small funnel when working on a project. Attached files are

  • The Not Very Big Funnel (50mm). As you can see in the picture it's less than half the size of a normal household funnel. I printed this one in clear PETG with a .8 mm nozzle.
  • The Smaller Funnel (40 mm) was the one I used for the project. Normal .4 mm nozzle and neon coloured PLA.
  • I realized I could make it smaller. The Tiny Funnel has a diameter of just 32 mm. I printed it in PETG using a .25 mm nozzle.
  • Yet smaller, 24mm, is Ze Smallestest Funnel.
  • ...but with a lot of patience, I made an even smaller one (18mm), which fits inside the Ze Smallestest Funnel. It's the kind the Smurfs use to fill mushroom juice in their tiny flasks.

The funnel is available as a customizable OpenSCAD model. The attached drawing shows the parameters you can tweak. Enjoy!

About the size of a poker chip. Has a raised Raven Tools logo on it. Originally built using an imported SVG of the Raven Tools logo in Blender and adding the disc underneath. Exported as an STL and resized in Makerware. New version built in OpenSCAD using an Inkscape Plugin to convert the Raven Tools SVG logo to something that could be placed on the disk.

title: Universal Fidget Spinner to Spinning Top Converter

description.text:
Are there too many fidget spinners laying around your house?
Did you print them, buy them or got them as a gift?
Are you bored spinning them in your hand?
Why not convert one or two of them to a regular spinning top? :-)
  • should work for every fidget spinner with a 608 center bearing and a standard thickness
  • swap the center bearing for one of my support free printed converters
  • spinning top!
  • had the idea a while back, but it took some time to "get it right"
  • I made many designs and options to choose from
  • haven´t seen anything like this yet, and I really wanted to see if it would work
  • modeled in Fusion 360, model units are [mm]
I know there are a lot of different files, so here is a little guide for you to choose the correct ones:

1) every filename consists of 3 blocks divided by an underline "_"
2) look at the "design type" picture to choose a design you like, this defines the first block
3) look at the "tip type" picture to choose a printed pointy tip, or an inserted steel ball as tip, this defines the second block (Steel balls work great for hard surfaces like glass or metal)
4) Choose if you want to print the converter in one part, standing up (brim recommended) or consisting of multiple parts for easier printing, this defines the third block

  • bottom parts for multipart versions are the same for all designs, you just need to choose the tip type. Ball tip type does not need a pin for alignment.
  • modeled to press fit into the empty 608 pockets
  • if the fit is not right for you, try scaling the model +/- 1%, or use a layer of tape to increase pressure
  • modeled to fit 13mm diameter steel balls and 1/2" steel balls (_inch models)
  • Please let me know if you have any problems with the models
  • I plan on creating more designs in the future

A washable wearable. What if you wanted a wearable computer, but wanted to wash the clothing? What if you wanted to use the same computer in many different pieces of clothes?

This holder holds a battery and a CircuitPlayground, You can sew the holder(s) to your clothes: arm bands,wrist bands, head band... and then move the one CircuitPlayground from item to item -- depending on what you are wearing that day.

Oh, and you can wash your clothes without the computer in them.

This is a holder for a circuit playground, and a LiPo battery pack, with holes on the back to sew it to an article of clothing. We have sewn it onto wrist bands, but these could be sewn onto armbands, head bands, shirts, jackets, etc... You can program your circuit playground to flash lights for visibility and safety, make noises, to make noise and lights when you dance, or whatever.

The design allows the battery and CircuitPlayground to be removed easily so that the clothing item can be washed. (Because, fellow makers, unwashed clothing eventually smells.)

It was designed for an ImagineRIT (Science Fair) by a group of Women in Tech. Original idea by Gauri Khodaskar, with embellishments by Cynthia Zachar, Marissa Haddock, Ariel Viggiano. Amiee Jackson measured the parts and converted Gauri's concept art into a 3D design.

Professor Thomas Kinsman did the product testing and development. This is the third revision, which a hole was added for ease of removing the CircuitPlayground by removing the battery first. Other holes were added to help remove the rafting and support material that is formed during the 3D printing process.

There are two versions of this design, one for an Adafruit 1200 mAh LiPo battery, and another for a 2000 mAh battery.
NGSS

Top view, with the NeoPixels in orange mode. The CircuitPlayground is above the LiPo battery. The red and black wires is a connector from the battery to the CircuitPlayground. Side view of wrist. Velcro closure is on the back. The lights in green. Shown here crocheted onto a wrist band, with a velcro closure. Nine holes are on each side for sewing. Thsi shows that you can push out the CircuitPlayground easily, by first sliding out the battery pack (inside) and then pushing the CircuitPlayground out from the back. It was Gauri Khodaskar's idea initially, Marissa Haddock did the sewing, Amiee Jackson did the initial build, and Cindy Zacher and Ariel Viggiano helped in other ways.

Fabricated in PLA on a 3D printer.
We found that making this flat was the easiest orientation to use.

description.text:
This is a very, very basic dry filament storage solution. It's nothing fancy. I dd not add Bowden tubes to feed the filament to my machines, and I did not use rods to hold the filament up because I wanted a "grab & go" solution. All you absolutely need is an airtight container & some reusable dessicant tins. The other bits here are just because I'm a little bit of an overengineer sometimes.

I used the Iris 62 quart weathertight storage box available on Amazon (link below). I did so because it had the greatest storage capacity for the average dimensions of standard 1kg filament spools. I can get 2 rows of 8 rolls each into a box, total 16 per box. Lots of boxes were too narrow for 2 rows of filament. I did not want filament spools stacked on top of one another- I wanted easy access. (With 500g/750g rolls, you can obviously get more than 16 rolls in a bin, depending on the width of the rolls)

I also put 2 40-gram silica gel dessicant packs into each box. Also available on Amazon (link below), and they are reusable. They have an indicator that changes color when they are saturated & you just bake them for a few hours to dry them out again. Mine have now been in use for 8 months, and are still going strong.

Here's where I went a little overboard. I decided I didn't want the filament resting directly on those dessicant tins. I can't even tell you why- I thought a little air gap would be good, if for no other reason than circulation. So I bought some 2" and 3" PVC pipe from my local hardware store. For the specific bins I am using, I cut 2 lengths of the 2" PVC to 20" each for the outer edge of the bin, and 1 length of the 3" PVC to 19.75" for the center of the bin. The reason for the thicker PVC in the center was to force the rolls towards the edges so they wouldn't try to overlap in the center of the bin. (Again, I overthought this)

***You will want to measure your own containers if you decide to do this. Remember to measure at the BOTTOM, because the top is always wider. Also remember to measure inside any curved edges so your tubes fit all the way to the bottom of the bin.

Of course, the PVC on the edges would be pressed into place by the weight of the spools. But the one in the center might move around if the weight was not evenly distributed, so I made some brackets to lift it up slightly, and then glued some scrap rubber to the bottom to make them slip-resistant. It's not perfect, but removing 1 or 2 rolls won't let the center tube slip & slide. I didn't use the stickiest rubber possible. Yours may work better.

Links to items used:

Iris 62 quart weathertight container:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003KWJ9TS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

40 gram Silica gel reusable dessicant tin (use 2 per container):
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0001EJIXK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

comments.text: Thank you so much for specifying the model and capacity of the box! I've been digging for days through various sealed boxes from several companies trying to find one that would store (and serve) spools efficiently! The frustration comes from the fact that they always list outside (handle-to-handle) dimensions, so you cannot calculate based on spool size how many they can hold (I have one I need to return to the store that has 4.5" less internal length than outside/advertised length).
comments.author: glabifrons

comments.text: You are very welcome.  That part was the main reason for even posting this.  Too many containers out there that are just a little too small in one direction or another.
comments.author: glabifrons

comments.text: Interesting solution. You must be in a very dry area. 1000g of desiccant lasts me about 3-4 weeks before I have to dry it out again, and that's in a 4 up container. 40g is just a drop in the bucket.
comments.author: 1BigE

comments.text: Actually, I live just outside Tampa, Florida.  Most of the year here is very humid.  But we run the air conditioner for 10 months out of the year, so the humidity inside the house likely stays fairly low.  I could probably get away with storing filament in the open, aside from nylon, but I needed a storage solution and figured I'd hedge my bets a bit.

These handy, modular clips are designed to hold a sheet of metal or card in order to block any stray beams from your optical table - we used some nice corrugated, black-annodised aluminium. Being able to mix and match allows you to quickly drop in or remove sections of your beam block and split your table into sections without having to install large lengths of material or a gantry around the table. You could also use them as holders for alignment targets. These are designed for metric tables (the design captures an M6 caphead screw) but should also work with imperial tables (and 1/4"-20 caphead screws).

Print a bunch of the different variations - you never know what your experiment may call for in the future... We found that the 3-way and right-angled 2-way pieces are really handy, so print more of those. Drop an M6 (or 1/4"-20) caphead screw into the hole in the top of the mount and use a ball driver to push this through the base and mount to your optical table. Place a few around your table and connect them with some sheets of metal or card.

title: X-Carriage et al for FLSun i3 (2017 edition)

description.text:
This carriage and components were designed to work on the FLSun i3 2017 edition. It may work on more units, however.
I wanted a new X-Carriage because the original acrylic unit warped after just a few months of use. I printed this in PLA and seems to be holding up just fine, but eventually, I will print it all in ABS.
This package has a few features that you may find interesting:

1) The X-Carriage has a standard cable chain mount to hook up an X-Chain.
The link STL files (CableChain.stl and CableChainx4.stl) included here are not made by me. I wanted to use the defacto standard ones made by ModelStation. The original design can be sourced here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11978

2) The rear holes on the carriage are larger than the bolts that come with the i3 unit. The reason is so you can adjust the tightness of the wheels against the 2020 extrusion. I have included an eccentric nut for print. These insert into the larger holes so you can turn them to snug the wheels to the X rail. These two bolts need to be longer than stock. 30mm does the trick. No longer than that though, otherwise the bolt will hit the left Z mount before it can get to the end stop X micro switch.

3) The Commode parts cooler fits on the front and comes in two flavors. You can use the one with LED mounts so light up the parts area if you are using a camera for time lapse. Alternatively, you can use the no LED version if lighting up the area is not to your liking.

4) I created an X end-stop spacer so you don’t need to use two 4mm T-nuts to prop up the micro switch as the instructions say.

5) Print two of the hot end clips (HotEndClip.stl). These surround the hot end mounting slot at the top to hold it in place rather than using the aluminum strip that comes with the kit. 3mm 12mm long bolts are what you need here.

6) The BLTouchMountWithCableGuide.stl and the RadialFanMount.stl files are made to mount to the X-Carriage and be fully adjustable.

7) ZMount.stl is the chain clip that mounts to the 2020 extrusion on the right side of the printer.

8) X_fixed_end.stl is a part I got from Thingiverse but I didn’t write down the original author. (If the original owner of this part stumles across this thing, please let me know and I will update it, giving credit.) It is used to join the X chain to the Z chain and mount to the Z plate on the right side of the printer. Another longer than stock (30mm ) bolt is needed to mount this. This part doesn’t fit quite right on my printer but good enough for now. I will eventually redesign this part and update this Thing.

What you will need:
3 - M5 30mm bolts (two for the X carriage eccentric and one for the X to Z chain mount on Z bracket)
2 – M3 10mm bolts for RadialFanMount to X-carriage.
4 – M3 12mm bolts
3 – M3 16mm holt ( 1 for BLTouch mount and two for Commode parts cooler to RadialFanMount)

DO NOT print Asselbled.stl. It is just an STL of most of the parts fit together so you can see in 3D how it all fits together.

Print one of everything except Eccentric.stl and HotEndClip.stl. You will need two of these parts.

Of course you will need to print many chain links if you are going that route. I use 23 on the X axis and 29 on the Z.

UPDATE Aug 29, 2017:
Added two more parts cooler options called SimpleWithLEDs.stl and SimpleNoLEDs.stl. I like this parts cooler better as it doesn't surround the hot end and require very precise positioning. It also moves a lot more air across the part. Curious if other people like it more than a fang as I do.

description.text:
Purpose

This is a mount for a replacement power supply unity for the Anet A8.

Compatibility

To make sure, the PSU fits, compare it's dimensions with the dimension chart above (images section).

Needed additional parts:

You will need the following screws to mount the psu:

  • 4x M4 x 16, head: truss head or barrel head (~4mm thickness, max. 8mm diameter)

15-20%

Notes:

Size accuracy matters! So make sure your printer is well adjusted.

Before working on the PSU

Before you do any work on electronics, make sure the power line is unplugged! Never work on electronic circutes without unplugging it.

Step 1: Attach Frame to PSU

Mount the thing to the PSU using the M4 screws. The surface labeled "TOP" (will be printed into the frame") needs to be placed on the PSU side (not A8 frame side) between the top M4 threads of the PSU.
Simply use the M4 screws to attach the frame to the PSU. The screw heads will fit into the recesses.

Step 2: Make sure everything fits

Hold the PSU including the mount in the final position and make sure everything fits well.

In my case I had to bend some aluminium splines of the PSU to create a little space for the screw which holds the acrylic mount for the right Z-axis stepper motor. This will not harm the PSU terribly and does not make any difference in functionality or safety.

In any case it is very important that the mounted PSU does NOT create any bracing or strong force to your printer's frame. If you cannot gently tighten the screws without applying much force or the threads do not fit the drillings, do not mount the PSU! You might hurt or event break your acrylic frame.

Step 3: Mount the PSU

Use the M3 screws to attach the PSU to the printer's frame. Use the washers under the screw heads to spread the pressure on the acrylic frame. Hint: I would do this for any screws that are thightened against the acrylic frame.

The screws are screwed into the mount without using any nuts.

title: iPhone 7 Plus Otterbox Defender 2016 Ford F150 Tray

description.text: An iPhone 7 Plus in an Otterbox Defender is too big for a 2016 Ford F150's jump seat phone tray. I made this to get around that.

comments.text: Can you provide the dimensions for the cell phone area? I want to use this for a different phone. How well does it stay put in the armrest tray? Thank you for uploading this.
comments.author: patrickoneal

comments.text: You are very welcome. The interior of the phone tray is 96mm X 180mm X 18mm. I made it slightly bigger than an iPhone 7 Plus housed in an Otterbox Defender so that it would be easy to get in and out. The part that sits in the armrest is very snug and requires the tiniest bit of sanding on the corners to fit perfectly, but once it's in there, it is very stable. A note of caution: do NOT print this using PLA. My original melted under hot car conditions. I had another printed using ABS, but the weather has cooled significantly since then and I don't know how that will hold up under summertime conditions yet. If you print this, please let me know how it turns out for you. Best Regards
comments.author: patrickoneal

title: Pixel XL Dock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple, compact dock for the Pixel XL. It's designed to use the cables that comes with the phone, others may work I don't know. It's easy to insert and remove the cable thanks to the insert.stl. The cable is managed in a track with a clips so it doesn't interfere with the stand (push up, make it wobble, etc). I've added 90deg speaker ports (yes there's only one speaker but I like it symmetrical). The stand is very sturdy and it's easy to dock/undock the phone.

My cable is beat up from using a different phone stand on here that required hot glue to keep the cable from moving... it didn't work. This dock will not damage your cable. If anything it'll help it last longer by keeping it very secure in the stand.

I was able to slot in the cable without trouble but I gave it to someone else to try and they couldn't get it. Apparently they used a set of needle nose pliers, not to hold the cable but to push it up into the slot where it protrudes from the top, since you can't get your fingers in there.

There are 3 files. You need the Insert.stl and _nocase.stl unless you're using my honeycomb case: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2423891 then you'll need the _case.stl instead.

title: Kossel Top Spool Holder Using 608 Bearing

description.text:
Important:

to prevent the filament from tangling underneath the spool, guide the filament like i do or use other existing filament guides in this site.

The 'center' part have a rod that is weak and may break easily, use the included insert.stl and plug it in the hole to strengthen (REMEMBER TO PRINT IT LAY FLAT ON YOUR BED ) it or preferably use a long m4 screw like i do, other strong rods that have a diameter less than 4mm could also be used.

to implement this, you will need to print:
3 beam.stl
1 SpoolFixer.stl
1 Certer.stl
1 Rotor.stl
also you will need some m3 screws and nuts, at least one 608 bearing (2 is preferred), this type of bearing is also known as the skateboard bearing or fidget spinner bearing.

if you want to mount it into the 2020 aluminium profile (which is actually not needed, it can just snap in, just make sure it is fitted right), check out my m3 t-nut: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2469130

The extended version of the center is for extra wide spools, if you have spool that is wider than 7cm then you should use it instead.

print_settings.Notes:: Since you won't touch these as you would with a controller, the mounts that are attached to the 2020 extrusions doesn't really need much infill but I still suggest you use at least 20% infill and 3 perimeters due tightening of the M3 and M5 bolts.

description.text:
Got worried that the E3D cooling fan would stop suddenly and damage the printer. Bought a couple of cheap volt meters to keep track of everything and needed a mount. The plan is to have the three volt meters checking the E3D fan (12V aux pins on the RAMPS board), heated bed (since I'm using a relay) and the E3D hotend. You may of course use them for whatever.

The mount is assembled using 2x M3 nuts and bolts (13mm+ length) and mounted on the standard 2020 aluminium extrusions using 2x 10mm M5 bolts and T-slot nuts. I recommend using a ball-tip allen wrench for the top M5 bolts since the angle of the mount blocks straight vertical tools.

The mount should fit most small digital volt meters which has a display size of 23mm x 15mm.

The ones I got: https://www.kjell.com/se/sortiment/el-verktyg/verktyg/matinstrument/panelinstrument/luxorparts-digital-voltmeter-0-99-v-dc-bla-led-p48372

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

0.2mm

20% or more is recommended

Notes:

Since you won't touch these as you would with a controller, the mounts that are attached to the 2020 extrusions doesn't really need much infill but I still suggest you use at least 20% infill and 3 perimeters due tightening of the M3 and M5 bolts.
Initial designs were made in 123Design but finished in Blender.

comments.author: dan3008

print_settings.Notes:: Supports are required for the Holder.stl, all other parts can be printed without.

description.text:
The Transformers Armada Unicron toy was designed to sit horizontally on a table, but can't stand on its own vertically. I designed this stand to allow it to both display in the vertical profile, and be tall enough to tower over top of smaller toys. I also designed a shorter display.

Most of this stand can be printed, but it does require a 5/16 steel rod for the central support. It was designed to work with a 5.75" to 6.5" rod length without becoming too top heavy. Anything shorter will bring Unicron's ring too close to the brace arms of the base. Steel rod can be purchased for a few dollars at most home improvement stores, such as Menards, Lowes, Home Depot, Ace Hardware, etc.

I printed this with 15% infill, and it's working fine, but increasing the infill will also increase the rigidity of the arms and the holder that Unicron rests on. The holder must be printed using support. Printing the holder in the orientation provided will leave the less smooth side with the supports hidden on the top, where the figure rests. You can also rotate the holder 90 degrees, onto its side, where the support will only appear along one edge. This makes the support look clean on both top and bottom, but takes twice as long to print.

The arms fit very tightly into the t-slots of the arm connector. If your printer over-extrudes, it may be difficult to fit them together without a bit of sanding. I was able to press-fit them together by hand, but I designed them with tight tolerances to maintain a good brace with the central rod of the stand.

I printed the object pictured in PLA Plus. PLA is the recommended material for the rigidity it gives to the holder, where most of the figure's weight is balanced. PETG might work, but would also have slightly more flexibility.
